awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Engineering Functional Tissue Assembly and Remodeling Through Developmental Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Tissue assembly and remodeling occurs at significantly faster rates during embryogenesis than in adulthood, but these mechanisms are poorly understood. Efficient strategies to control tissue adaptation and remodeling, as well as accelerate the construction of cardiovascular tissue replacements, can be gained by harnessing "natural engineering" paradigms that prescribe cardiovascular development and maturation.  This proposal will uncover these mechanisms for heart valves, a critically important cardiovascular soft tissue.  The guiding hypothesis is that heart valve tissue assembly and remodeling is controlled by a mechanically sensitive genetic signaling network that is active during valvulogenesis and reactivated in aged valves.

This proposal addresses a fundamental gap in our understanding of tissue assembly and remodeling processes with unique experimental and computational tools. These studies will provide first mechanistic insights integrating organ, tissue, cell, and molecular length scales that will transform engineering strategies to control valvular remodeling at any stage in the lifecycle. Implementation of a novel living embryo culture system will enhance inquiry based learning curricula. Assimilation of developmental biology and engineering at the graduate level will give specialized students much needed breadth. 

Unique experimental tools suitable for mouse tissues will enable quantitative mechanistic understanding of important functional consequences of sublethal genetic mutations. The visible living embryo system implemented in this proposal can be used as a centerpiece to communicate many basic phenomena to the general public as well as the scientific community. 

This will augment awareness and appreciation for the advancement of science.

por.por_cntn:
Heart valves perform critical functions to maintain one-way blood flow through the heart. They originate as weak gelatinous "cushions" along the early tubular heart wall, but progressively remodel into compliant but strong thin fibrous leaflets. While much was known about the molecular regulation of the early initiation events in cushion formation, much less is known about what governs the important remodeling functions that are essential for efficient long term function. While almost all studies in this area focus on genetic regulation, this proposal focused on informing how mechanical signaling controls the integrated molecular and cellular regulation of heart valve formation, remodeling, and homeostasis. Through this proposal, we developed and implemented a number of innovative technologies to quantify and study how mechanical forces drive valve cell response and tissue reorganization. We first quantified the age-dependent tissue biomechanics of heart valves, using mouse as a mammalian model. We found valves stiffen as they age, which correlated with a progressive accumulation of collagen. We also found that the cells embedded in this matrix were uniquely sensitive to this gross tissue deformation. Interestingly, we determined in a mouse model of human valve disease that the resident cells were unable to sense and/or respond to the local mechanical signaling, which may explain the poor remodeling and strength seen in those tissues. Our next goal was to understand how cyclic stretch controls valve cell behaviors in embryonic and adult cells. Using the chick model for embryonic valve cells, we determined that cyclic stretch activated a unique mechanobiological switch potentiating between two specific downstream signaling programs, each performing an important role in tissue formation and remodeling. Elevation or depletion of mechanical signaling in vivo was then able to accelerate or retard fetal valvular elongation. In our last goal, we developed a novel systems biological model incorporating multiple networks known to regulate aspects of endothelial to mesenchymal transformation (a key event in valve formation), and we then simulated outcomes to predict the principal molecular regulators of the process. Our simulations predicted the existence of novel hybrid cell behaviors, and identified two regulatory proteins that may be essential for this process. We then validated the regulation of these in vitro. 

During this proposal period, we invested heavily in community engagement for science literacy and STEM education. We brought our novel live embryo culture system into the K-12 class setting, and co-developed and taught grade appropriate science modules throughout the academic years. We further implemented a 3 day workshop on engineering and biology using our embryo system developed in this proposal. Students were able to conduct their own experiments and detail observations and conclusions like real scientists. We interacted with hundreds of students, parents, and teachers over the course of the project through these events and when showcased at the state fair. We revealed at least as many new questions to pursue as we answered in this proposal, and hope that some of the students we impacted will become future scientists to tackle these challenges.

Modified by: Jonathan T Butcher
